# Lecture 10 — Characteristic Directions
Primary PRIMITIVE: **SAMENESS-B**  
Neighbors to contrast: **DIRECTION**, **ARRANGEMENT**

One-line thesis:
- After this, students can find directions that a transformation does not “mix” — it only scales them.

## 1) Diagnosis
Recognition sentence:
- **“The transformation has special directions that come back parallel to themselves.”**

Fast checks:
- [ ] Output is parallel to input for some nonzero vectors.
- [ ] In those directions, the transformation acts like “stretch/shrink only.”
- [ ] Those directions explain the geometry (axes of an ellipse) or the physics (principal axes).

Boundary line:
- **DIRECTION** gives you arrows.
- **SAMENESS-B** asks which arrows stay “the same direction” after the allowed operation.

## 2) What exists here (spec)
- Object: a square matrix \(A\).
- Characteristic direction: a nonzero \(\vec v\) such that \(A\vec v=\lambda \vec v\).
- “Same” means: direction unchanged (up to scaling).
- “Different” means: direction mixed into others.

## 3) What you compute
Primary quantities:
- Eigenvalues \(\lambda\) and eigenvectors \(\vec v\).

Interpretation:
- \(\lambda\) = scale factor along that direction.
- \(\vec v\) = the direction that stays aligned.

## 4) Operation
Operation: solve \((A-\lambda I)\vec v=0\) for nonzero \(\vec v\).

## 5) Tool ladder
**L0:** push a vector through \(A\); most directions change, a few stay aligned.  
**L1:** definition \(A\vec v=\lambda\vec v\).  
**L2:** for symmetric \(A\), eigenvectors are orthogonal and define principal axes.  
**L3:** normal modes, principal axes, and PCA all use characteristic directions.

## 6) One theorem that matters
**Theorem (2D):** A symmetric \(2\times2\) matrix has two orthogonal eigenvectors.

Proof sketch:
- Symmetric \(A\) has real eigenvalues.
- If \(A\vec v_1=\lambda_1\vec v_1\) and \(A\vec v_2=\lambda_2\vec v_2\) with \(\lambda_1\neq\lambda_2\),
  then \(\vec v_1\cdot \vec v_2=0\).
- Reason: \(\vec v_1^\top A\vec v_2 = (A\vec v_1)^\top \vec v_2\) for symmetric \(A\).
- Substitute eigen-relations to get \(\lambda_2(\vec v_1\cdot\vec v_2)=\lambda_1(\vec v_1\cdot\vec v_2)\).
- So \((\lambda_2-\lambda_1)(\vec v_1\cdot\vec v_2)=0\Rightarrow \vec v_1\cdot\vec v_2=0\).

What it buys you:
- A symmetric transformation chooses its own “natural coordinate axes.”

## 7) One real computation (from shipped data)
Dataset:
- File: `assets/lessons/10-characteristic-directions/data/eigen_toy.csv`

Task:
- Read the 2×2 matrix \(A\).
- Compute eigenvalues/eigenvectors (by hand for 2×2, or verify numerically).
- Interpret eigenvectors as ellipse axes.

Sanity checks:
- Trace = sum of eigenvalues.
- Determinant = product of eigenvalues.

## 8) Invariance test (link to Lecture 09)
Under rotation of coordinates, eigenvalues of a matrix representing the same quadratic form stay the same.
Interpretation: eigenvalues are invariants; eigenvectors rotate with the frame.

## 9) Chemistry anchors
### Anchor A — Principal axes of inertia (rigid body intuition)
- You see: a mass distribution.
- You compute: principal axes (eigenvectors).
- You conclude: rotation “decouples” in those axes.

### Anchor B — Vibrational normal modes (preview)
- You see: coupled coordinates.
- You compute: eigenvectors of a force-constant matrix.
- You conclude: normal modes are characteristic directions of coupled motion.

### Anchor C — PCA on spectral datasets
- You see: many correlated measurements.
- You compute: eigenvectors of covariance.
- You conclude: a few directions capture most variance.

## 10) Notebook spec (Pluto)
Notebook: `notebooks/Lecture_10_Characteristic_Directions.jl`
- Sliders: symmetric matrix entries \(a, b, c\) with \(A=\begin{pmatrix}a&b\\b&c\end{pmatrix}\).
- Visual: ellipse + eigenvectors updating live.
- Structure check: verify trace/det invariants vs eigenvalues.

## 11) Misconceptions (tests)
- If you think eigenvectors are “just magic,” test \(A\vec v\) and check it stays parallel.
- If you think eigenvectors are always orthogonal, try a non-symmetric matrix.

## 12) Code interpretation
- Code computes eigendecomposition and draws the geometry so you can see “characteristic directions” rather than memorize a formula.
